results.title: The Secretary transcribes
results.brief_description: Begins by showing the difference between the work of a stenographer and that of a secretary. The importance of a systematic approach to work is stressed. The efficient secretary is shown at work. She keeps a card file of frequently-used addresses and knows the use of reference books. She uses a clear system in transcribing shorthand notes and checks her work while it is still in the typewriter, and is thus able to correct mistakes quickly and neatly.

results.title: The Secretary takes dictation
results.brief_description: Illustrates correct procedures and details in taking dictation. The film shows two employees, one a competent secretary and the other an inexperienced stenographer, taking dictation and contrasts the procedures used by them. The film emphasises that careful organisation, neatness and attention to details are essential in an efficient secretary.

group_works.title: Try to see it my way (NP)

results.title: The Secretary's day
results.brief_description: Shows how a secretary goes about arranging her work for the day. She begins by making out an appointment sheet for her employer and then deals with the mail, both business and personal; takes dictation, arranges her employer’s itinerary, handles callers, writes letters and supervises other workers. Before she leaves work she makes out her duties for the following day. The film distinguishes between the work of a stenographer and that of a secretary and emphasises the value to a business of an efficient staff.

results.title: The Secret world of Odilon Redon
results.creator_credit: Kevala Films, Stephen Cross and Rodney Wilson
results.brief_description: Odilon Redon was a major figure in the French Symbolist movement. He dedicated his art to “bringing to life improbable beings”, searching for them in the world of dreams. The film shows many of his early charcoal drawings and lithographs and ends with his pastels and oils and the frescoes of “Night” and “Day” at the Abbay de Fontfroide.

results.title: The Secret way
results.brief_description: Uses animated puppets to tell the story of a mischievous small boy who sets traps for birds, gets lost in the forest, is rescued by a crow, and learns to give sympathy and care to his non-human neighbours on the farm.

results.title: The Secret sharer
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films, Larry Yust and Joseph Conrad
results.brief_description: A screen adaptation of a Joseph Conrad short story. This film concerns a young, inexperienced sea captain’s encounter with a fugitive from naval justice. Follows the captain endangering his ship through helping the fugitive, and shows how he regains control.

results.title: The Secret policeman's other ball
results.creator_credit: Amnesty International, Martin Lewis, Peter Walker and Julien Temple
results.brief_description: Featuring some of Britain’s most loved and highly respected entertainers of comedy and rock music, this filmed live performance at the Theatre Royal, Drury Lane, London is an absolute ball - witty, outrageous, political, funny, but most of all, entertaining. It combines the winning elements of comedy sketches including some memorable Monty Python skits, stand-up comedy, and music performances by such stars as Rowan Atkinson, John Cleese, Tim Brooke-Taylor, Graham Chapman, Alexei Sayle, Bob Geldof, Jeff Beck, Eric Clapton, Donovan, Sting, Phil Collins and even Australia’s own inimitable Barry Humphries. Also features a special guest appearance by Michael Palin. Presented by Amnesty International with all royalties from the video going to Amnesty International. Stage show directed by Ronald Eyre.

results.title: The Secret of the Murray
results.creator_credit: Richard Walker and Australian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Explorers [Bill Peach]”.
Dramatised documentary written and presented by Bill Peach recounting the exploration of New South Wale’s river system. In 1828, Charles Sturt, a young English army captain lacking formal qualifications or practical bushman skill, was chosen to explore Australia’s western rivers. Hamilton Hume was appointed second in charge of the expedition and provided the guidance and support that enabled Sturt to unlock the secrets of Australia’s rivers and explode the myth that Australia was a giant basin with its waters draining into an inland sea. His greatest feat was charting the course of the Murray River to the sea. Sturt was an ambitious man who never achieved the high rank that he desired. In an act of ambitious flattery he named the Murray river after the Secretary for the Colonies rather than recognise the discovery made by Hume and Hovell.

Hamilton Hume was appointed second in charge of the expedition and provided the guidance and support that enabled Sturt to unlock the secrets of Australia’s rivers and explode the myth that Australia was a giant basin with its waters draining into an inland sea. His greatest feat was charting the course of the Murray River to the sea. Sturt was an ambitious man who never achieved the high rank that he desired. In an act of ambitious flattery he named the Murray river after the Secretary for the Colonies rather than recognise the discovery made by Hume and Hovell.
